resources.string: Let´s discover Barakaldo, from rural to modern!

Hi everyone! I´m Jolín, the most fun-loving character in Barakaldo! I´m so glad you´re here, because together we´re going to discover how this beautiful place has transformed from a rural village full of farmhouses into a modern, vibrant city. Along the way, we´ll visit some very special places, solve games and challenges, and learn amazing stories about our town.
Get your curious eyes and your eagerness to learn ready! Each time you complete a challenge, you´ll unlock old and new photos of Barakaldo! At the end of the journey… a surprise and a diploma await you for becoming true Barakaldo explorers!
Ready? Let´s go! Let´s discover Barakaldo, from rural to modern!

Many years ago, Barakaldo was a town surrounded by fields, farmhouses, and mountains. Families helped each other, grew their own food, and went to the hermitage of Santa Águeda to celebrate festivals and ask for protection. The hermitage was a very important place for the townspeople, because they gathered there to sing, eat, and share moments together. Over time, Barakaldo changed, but the hermitage still reminds us how it all began.
What things do you think are still the same?
a) The hermitage is still standing
b) There are no more mountains

The Church of San Vicente has been the heart of the village for many years. Here people gathered to pray, celebrate festivals, and meet with their neighbors. Look closely at the photo of the church and notice the elements that make it up: the Choir, the Altar, the Stations of the Cross, the Tabernacle, the Main Door, the Central Nave… Each one has its function and helps us understand what life was like in that time.

In the Barakaldo market, people bought food and met their neighbors. Typical products were sold here: Barakaldo beans, talos (corn tortillas), cod in pil-pil sauce, and homemade sweets. The market was a place full of smells, colors, and sounds. Look at the clues in the word search and find the words that correspond to these foods.
A very typical legume from Barakaldo, it is eaten in stews
It is eaten at parties and is made from corn.

The Ilgner building was very important for Barakaldo. Here, electricity was produced for the factories and workshops. Thanks to the energy, the machines could operate, and the city grew considerably. Engineers, mechanics, and electricians worked here. The building still stands and reminds us how modern industry began.

Many years ago, Barakaldo was a place full of factories and trains. Iron was extracted from the nearby mountains, and the loading docks were enormous structures used to load the ore onto ships. Trains brought the iron, and dockworkers moved it to the ships that carried it to other cities. Thanks to this work, Barakaldo became very important in industry.
This is where the trains carrying the iron arrived.
The iron was loaded onto ships that went to other countries.
The loading docks helped Barakaldo to grow a lot.

In industrial Barakaldo, trains transported iron ore from the mines to the loading docks, where it was loaded onto ships. Thanks to the railway, many factories could operate continuously, and workers traveled daily on these trains. The railway was one of the driving forces behind Barakaldo´s growth.

The Munoa Palace was the home of a very wealthy family. While many people worked in the factories, parties and dances were held here. It had gardens, paintings, and elegant furniture. Today, the Munoa Palace is a park open to everyone, where we can stroll and enjoy the history of Barakaldo.

Barakaldo has changed a lot from its rural origins to the present day. We have old factories, churches, palaces, and parks that tell its story. All these places are part of our heritage, and we must take care of them so that future generations can also know them.
